title: 'You can say "it's boxing" but it's hard to justify': Eddie Hearn cries as he discusses Patrick Day
text:
Eddie Hearn was visibly emotional when asked about the tragic death of boxer Patrick Day this week.

Day passed away on Wednesday after sustaining a brain injury during the 10th-round of his fight against Charles Conwell in Chicago last Saturday.

The bout took place on a card organised by Hearn's promotional company Matchroom Boxing USA, and in an interview with iFL TV, Hearn sheds some tears when talking about meeting Day two days before the fight, and his subsequent death.

Patrick Day in action on Saturday in Chicago before his tragic death caused in the 10th round

Eddie Hearn starts to well up when asked about his feelings towards Patrick Day and his death

The Matchroom promoter recalls meeting Day for the first time and becomes visibly upset

Hearn believes the sport of boxing must do more to protect fighters and look into measures

'It's tragic. I met Patrick Day last Thursday for the first time and I was left in absolute pieces, and I only knew him for 30 seconds,' explained Hearn.

‘It’s heartbreaking. He is a man who didn’t need to box, he had a family – he didn’t need that search for money, he did it because he loved the sport of boxing.'

The 27-year-old American was treated on the canvas at Chicago's Wintrust Arena on Saturday night before being carried out on a stretcher and then placed in a coma from which he never woke up.

Tributes have poured in for Day - this is a message from Kazakhstani boxer Gennadiy Golovkin

British fighter Tony Bellew also paid his respects with a message on his Twitter page

Hearn also praised the work of the medical team in Chicago, but nonetheless admitted the sport of boxing needs to look into measures to protect fighters more robustly.

Day is the fourth boxer to die after competing in a professional fight in 2019.

Russian Maxim Dadashev and Hugo Alfredo Santillan from Argentina died in July, while Bulgarian Boris Stanchov passed away following a fight in September.

‘You can say it’s boxing but it’s so hard to justify,' says Hearn.

Hearn admitted that the natural risk element of the sport meant nobody was to blame

‘It’s been a rough year for the sport so we need to make sure we get together as a community, keep trying to evolve, keep trying to make the sport safer.

‘We have to make sure that as a sport, we do better.

‘It’s boxing, and it’s very very dangerous. There’s so much more we can do. There’s no one to blame, it’s just the tragedy of the sport.'
description: Day passed away after sustaining a brain injury during the 10th round of his fight against Charles Conwell in Chicago last Saturday - the bout took place during Hearn's event.
